channel.title: NYT > Technology
channel.copyright: Copyright 2017 The New York Times Company

item.title: Push for Gender Equality in Tech? Some Men Say It’s Gone Too Far
item.media:description: James Damore was fired by Google last month after suggesting that there may be biological reasons for gender gaps in tech jobs.
item.media:credit: Jason Henry for The New York Times
item.description: After revelations of harassment and bias in Silicon Valley, a backlash is growing against the women in tech movement.
item.dc:creator: NELLIE BOWLES

item.title: One Surprise Standout for Uber: Food Delivery
item.media:description: The kitchen at Footprints Cafe Express in Brooklyn, whose owner, Bob Gordon, said the UberEats delivery service had been a boon to his business. Mr. Gordon also owns Footprints Cafe, a separate location.
item.media:credit: Sam Hodgson for The New York Times
item.description: Despite a late start, the company’s foray into delivering food, a cutthroat $100 billion-plus service industry, eclipses ride hailing in some markets.
item.dc:creator: MIKE ISAAC

item.title: Uber Loses License to Operate in London
item.media:description: The Uber Hub in London. Transport for London, which regulates ride-hailing services in the city, said the company’s “approach and conduct demonstrate a lack of corporate responsibility.”
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: London’s transportation agency criticized Uber’s corporate culture, the latest setback for a company that has faced an array of controversies this year.
item.dc:creator: PRASHANT S. RAO and MIKE ISAAC

item.title: State of the Art: On Russian Meddling, Mark Zuckerberg Follows a Familiar Playbook
item.description: Mr. Zuckerberg’s modus operandi as a leader is to fix things long after they have broken, rather than to prevent problems in the first place.
item.dc:creator: FARHAD MANJOO
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: Facebook Drops Stock Move That Would Have Solidified Zuckerberg’s Control
item.media:description: Mark Zuckerberg and his wife, Dr. Priscilla Chan. Mr. Zuckerberg plans to sell Facebook stock so their charitable initiative can finance work in fields like education and science.
item.description: The social network’s board withdrew a stock reclassification proposal after a shareholder suit that would have put Mr. Zuckerberg in a courtroom.
item.dc:creator: MIKE ISAAC

item.title: Editorial: Facebook’s Belated Awakening
item.media:description: Facebook’s founder and chief executive Mark Zuckerberg.
item.media:credit: Andrew Esiebo for The New York Times
item.description: As social media companies wield greater power in the political system, more safeguards are needed.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: Tech Tip: Resolutions for the Big (and Small) Screens
item.description: Many online services now offer three levels of picture quality for videos, but be sure to choose the best one for your device.
item.dc:creator: J. D. BIERSDORFER

item.title: Strategies: The Best Investment Since 1926? Apple
item.description: Apple has generated more wealth for shareholders than any other of the top 50 companies, which account for 40 percent of stock market wealth.
item.dc:creator: JEFF SOMMER

item.title: Bits: Farhad’s and Mike’s Week in Tech: A Very Bad Week for Digital Giants
item.media:description: Google is spending $1.1 billion to hire about 2,000 employees from HTC.
item.description: Apple’s Watch has a bug, Facebook might be undermining democracy, and Amazon is telling us how to make bombs. Tech news is weird right now.
item.dc:creator: FARHAD MANJOO and MIKE ISAAC

item.title: The Shift: Facebook’s Frankenstein Moment
item.media:description: Victor Frankenstein, looking over a creature he had made, eventually realized that he couldn’t control his creation.
item.description: A series of scandals have opened up the possibility that the company may have created something it can’t fully control.
item.dc:creator: KEVIN ROOSE

item.title: Facebook to Turn Over Russian-Linked Ads to Congress
item.media:description: Facebook said it would share more than 3,000 Russia-linked adds with two congressional committees investigating Russian influence on last year’s presidential campaign. The company previously showed congressional staff a sample of the ads, some of which attacked Hillary Clinton or praised Donald J. Trump, but had not shared the entire collection.
item.description: The company said it would turn over 3,000 ads linked to Russia to Congress after growing scrutiny about its role in last November’s presidential election.
item.dc:creator: SCOTT SHANE and MIKE ISAAC
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: Tech Tip: Retiring the Google Drive Desktop App
item.description: While its current desktop app for Windows and Mac is headed off into the sunset, Google has new apps for backing up and syncing files online.
item.dc:creator: J. D. BIERSDORFER

item.title: How to Hack Your Brain (for $5,000)
item.media:description: Jamie Wheal speaking to participants on the last night of Flow Camp in the “Flow Dojo” at Powder Mountain, Utah.
item.media:credit: Michael Friberg for The New York Times
item.description: The new, new, new age is all about “defragging our nervous systems.”
item.dc:creator: CASEY SCHWARTZ

item.title: Google Is Buying HTC’s Smartphone Expertise for $1.1 Billion
item.media:description: HTC employees were already working with Google on smartphone development before a $1.1 billion deal that was announced on Wednesday.
item.description: The deal bolsters Google’s ability to build mobile hardware and joins two companies already working together on one of Google’s upcoming Pixel phones.
item.dc:creator: DAISUKE WAKABAYASHI

item.title: S.E.C. Says It Was a Victim of Computer Hacking Last Year
item.media:description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said a digital attack last year may have exposed information that could have been exploited for trading purposes.
item.description: The commission said the attackers could have exploited private information for trading purposes.
item.dc:creator: ALEXANDRA STEVENSON and CARLOS TEJADA

item.title: Internet Giants Face New Political Resistance in Washington
item.media:description: Google’s headquarters in Mountain View, Calif. “There needs to be more aggressive enforcement action on tech companies like Google,” says Senator Richard Blumenthal, a Democrat from Connecticut.
item.media:credit: Christie Hemm Klok for The New York Times
item.description: Facebook, Google and Amazon are coming under increasing pressure by regulators concerned about their growing power.
item.dc:creator: CECILIA KANG

item.title: Former Apple Engineers Working on New Eyes for Driverless Cars
item.media:description: Soroush Salehian and Mina Rezk, of Aeva, a Silicon Valley start-up making new guidance systems for driverless vehicles.
item.media:credit: Jason Henry for The New York Times
item.description: The Silicon Valley start-up Aeva is developing new sensors that could significantly improve how autonomous vehicles see the road.
item.dc:creator: CADE METZ

item.title: Facebook, After ‘Fail’ Over Ads Targeting Racists, Makes Changes
item.media:description: Sheryl Sandberg, Facebook’s chief operating officer, said the company had never anticipated that its ad-targeting technology could be used to court users who described themselves as “Jew haters” or used other hate speech.
item.description: Sheryl Sandberg, Facebook’s chief operating officer, promised “more human review and oversight” to make sure offensive terms aren’t used to target ads.
item.dc:creator: SAPNA MAHESHWARI and MIKE ISAAC

item.title: Tech We’re Using: Avoiding Cameras While Training the Lens on Food
item.media:description: Pete Wells, The New York Times’s restaurant critic, at a Brooklyn restaurant this month.
item.media:credit: Sasha Maslov for The New York Times
item.description: Pete Wells, The Times’s restaurant critic, discussed how he avoids cameras to protect his identity and how technology has transformed the dining scene.
item.dc:creator: PETE WELLS

item.title: Europe Renews Offensive on Silicon Valley With Tax Reforms
item.media:description: Google’s offices, center, in Dublin last year. European Commission officials are investigating Google for allegedly abusing its dominant market position.
item.media:credit: Paulo Nunes dos Santos for The New York Times
item.description: A new set of proposals presented by officials in Brussels seek to tax technology companies differently, but risk being seen as an effort to target American tech giants.
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER

item.title: Toshiba Reaches Tentative Deal to Sell Microchip Unit
item.media:description: Toshiba’s semiconductor unit is the world’s second-largest producer of NAND flash memory.
item.description: The board of the Japanese conglomerate is close to an agreement with a group of investors led by Bain Capital, although details must still be finalized.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE

item.title: Tech Tip: Getting Social With Waze
item.description: The traffic app is great at giving directions and rerouting around jams, but it also includes features for drivers when they’re not on the road.
item.dc:creator: J. D. BIERSDORFER

item.title: Amazon ‘Reviewing’ Its Website After It Suggested Bomb-Making Items
item.media:description: A British TV station said Amazon’s website was prompting customers to buy all the ingredients to make a bomb.
item.description: A British television news report said that the online retailer’s algorithms were automatically offering items that could be used to create an explosive device.
item.dc:creator: AMIE TSANG

item.title: Tech Fix: Apple Watch Series 3 Excels, Even if You Don’t Need Cellular
item.media:description: Jeff Williams, Apple’s chief operating officer, presenting features of the new Apple Watch at a company event last week. Cellular connectivity with the smartwatches is likely a luxury that most people probably will not need.
item.description: Date night without your iPhone? That’s now doable with the new cellular Apple Watch, which for the first time can be untethered from your smartphone. Here’s our review.
item.dc:creator: BRIAN X. CHEN

item.title: Before Wisconsin, Foxconn Vowed Big Spending in Brazil. Few Jobs Have Come.
item.media:description: A Foxconn-owned building in the state of São Paulo, Brazil, in 2012. The company’s plans to build one of the world’s biggest manufacturing hubs in Brazil have stalled.
item.media:credit: Ana Ottoni for The New York Times
item.description: The Taiwanese company’s manufacturing model has not translated easily to other countries, where it faces different social, political and labor conditions.
item.dc:creator: DAVID BARBOZA

item.title: The iPhone 8 Reviews: What the Critics Say
item.media:description: The iPhone 8, left, and 8 Plus.
item.description: Reviewers considered the phones a modest upgrade over the iPhone 7 and 7 Plus, but several suggested waiting for the iPhone X.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL VICTOR

item.title: An Earthquake Hits and Angelenos Shelter on Twitter
item.media:description: Monday night’s earthquake hit a few miles away from Westwood, Calif., an area near Bel Air, Beverly Hills and Santa Monica.
item.description: It may have been mild and standard, but it happened in Los Angeles. So, naturally, earthquake was a trending topic on Twitter by early Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: VALERIYA SAFRONOVA

item.title: Book News: YouTube Star Hank Green Will Publish His First Novel Next Year
item.description: Following in the footsteps of his older brother, the best-selling novelist John Green, Hank Green will publish his first novel with Dutton.
item.dc:creator: ALEXANDRA ALTER

item.title: Tech Tip: Why Deleted Tweets Still Linger Online
item.description: Even if you kill a Twitter post from your timeline, a search engine may give it a second life until it updates its index files.
item.dc:creator: J. D. BIERSDORFER

item.title: State of the Art: The iPhone 8: A Worthy Refinement Before the Next Generation
item.media:description: The iPhone 8, left, and the 8 Plus both have processors that are significantly faster than the iPhone 7’s.
item.description: Apple’s new iPhone 8 and 8 Plus have a ring of familiarity. But the phones may feel like a solid upgrade from older models because of their new processor.
item.dc:creator: FARHAD MANJOO

item.title: High Tech Meets High Art in a 3-D Opera
item.media:description: Miah Persson, live onstage, and Roderick Williams, in film, in “Blank Out,” by Michel van der Aa, who has become known for combining traditional opera and high-tech elements.
item.description: Michel van der Aa’s “Blank Out,” at the Park Avenue Armory, brings together a live singer onstage and another who appears only in a 3-D film.
item.dc:creator: NINA SIEGAL

item.title: Tech Tip: Outlook for Android, Plain and Simple
item.description: Microsoft’s mobile version of Outlook for the Android platform doesn’t offer text-formatting options, but it does manage your mailbox.
item.dc:creator: J. D. BIERSDORFER

item.title: How the Internet Kept Humming During 2 Hurricanes
item.media:description: Rain from Hurricane Harvey last month pummeling the Skybox data center west of Houston.
item.description: While millions lost electricity across Florida, and thousands of homes and businesses were flooded in Miami and Texas, the data centers powering the internet held firm.
item.dc:creator: JAMES GLANZ

item.title: Facebook Faces a New World as Officials Rein In a Wild Web
item.media:description: Vietnam’s government has said Facebook agreed to help create a new communications channel with the government.
item.description: The web is not as open as it once was, with nation-states exerting their power over the internet. Facebook and other tech companies are dealing with the consequences.
item.dc:creator: PAUL MOZUR, MARK SCOTT and MIKE ISAAC

item.title: How Facebook Is Changing Your Internet
item.description: Behind the scenes, Facebook is involved in high-stakes diplomatic battles across the globe that have begun fragmenting the internet itself.

item.title: Mediator: Facebook Knows More About Russia’s Election Meddling. Shouldn’t We?
item.media:description: A Facebook mural on the company’s campus in 2014. Facebook is under fire for running ads purchased by fake users trying to cause disruption in the American electorate.
item.description: The social media giant owes it to its users to let them know if they interacted with what amounts to a digital spy. And that’s just the start.
item.dc:creator: JIM RUTENBERG
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
